abstract.para: The topic covers FAQ a package mantaine may have.

question.para: I want to define a lifecycle for my package, what should I do?

answer.para: Raise a Jira ticket so we can track and document the process. If you are not sure about the lifecycle category, contact you manager and a &slea; architect.

question.para: Which type of lifecycle can or should I adopt?

answer.para: The further down in the stack your component is, the bigger number of packages depend on it, so the more conservative approach you should choose. When in doubt, contact &slea; architects.

question.para: I think I want to use a balanced lifecycle for my package. Should I go for several versions in parallel?

answer.para: In general, it is better to replace the old package with a new version, it creates less overhead on the maintainer side and it is less confusing to customers. A sliding window is useful for most toolchain components that have API or ABI changes as part of new releases. However, the particular approach depends on the amount and type of changes. For example, if the changes can be adopted easily or even automated, then it is better to just update the package. When changes lead to conflicts that neither we nor the customer can easily resolve, then maintainig parallel version is a better options.
&suse; tried this case by case basis for Python modules.

question.para: Should I convert my package from a balanced lifecycle to an agile one, and release updated versions also to code streams under LTS?

answer.para: This is a question that we need to investigate in each case. In general, if the particular package is beneficial for customers on the older releases, then it may be worth to release the updated packages to older releases. For example, if a component is mostly about operations, then it may be useful for customers on older releases. On contrary, newer packages that provide hardware enablement are usually not needed, as customers' hardware has not changed since the time of installation.
